Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the calendar app open, two reminders blinking at me. Tonight was the annual family dinner, a tradition my stepmother insisted we all attend, especially this year. “It’s important to show we’re united,” she’d said, her eyes lingering on me a little longer than the others. I knew what she meant—being the step-child, I always felt I had to prove I belonged, to honor their customs as if they were my own.

But at the same time, my work chat pinged. “Don’t forget the team meeting at 7,” my manager wrote. “We’d love your input.” I was new to the team, eager to show I was committed, not just another face on the screen. The meeting would be recorded, but I knew being there live mattered—my absence would be noticed.

I felt the pressure mounting, my chest tightening. If I missed the dinner, I’d disappoint my family, maybe confirm their doubts about my place. If I skipped the meeting, I’d risk my standing at work. Both sides expected me to show up, to prove myself. I sat frozen, torn between two worlds, unsure which one I’d let down.
